review_blob: I tasted it next to an American brown, which I know is a different style.  And I know that Im not supposed to like macros.  But this stikes me nicely (at home; at the right temperature).  The sweet malt comes through but not nearly so much to pull it into porter/stout territory.  Lots of caramel and cherries.  Id love to taste it next to a Samuel Smiths.

I dont remember this one being so dark.  Typically, I drink it in an ill-lit bar, and in those instances my impression has always been that its sort of a well-balanced double pale ale.  Now I see that this puppy is pretty dark and malty.  The hops are still there, and its far from an extreme brown ale, but its tough to categorize the real balance of it between malt and hop.  Anyway its very bold, a bit syrupy, and powerful!

Why do I have a bias against Mendo brewing?  Is it because when I grew up, knowing nothing about beer, the only mendo Id see and drink was Red Tail Ale, and I hated it?  But Red Tail is an amber ale, and Ive learned that I just dont dig that style yet, so I cant blame Mendo.  That said, Im pleasantly suprised with this one.  Nice balance of apricot and a little grapefruit.  Not for those of us looking to burn off our tounge (and sometimes thats me), but this is a good, solid, well-balanced IPA.

Jet black, opaque. Coffee-colored head. Roasty smell.  Very roasted taste, but creamy and plenty of malt flavor. Very different than a Guinness (lots of people think they are they same style--they arent). That is, its a much sweeter, fuller flavor, yet still roasted.
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008

2007 bomber:
Very dark, opaque, with a coffee-colored head. Smells like a campfire (heavily smoked). Bitter and creamy palate. Flavor is tremendously smoky--really heavy with wood and bacon flavors. I feel like Im camping in Alaska :)
Flavor is very sweet; lots of caramel, adn chocolate that well overpower the bitterness. Very smooth finish. Rich.

Coffee-colored head. Black, opaque. Chocolaty smell. Taste is burnt malt and bitterness turning to rich chocolate. Substantial.
[Compared with a Sierra Nevada Porter]
The Sierra has a much more fruity nose compared to the chocolate Point Reyes. Guess that indicates it all: the Point Reyes is a chocalaty-rich dessert and the Sierra is another fantastic one, but very hopped.

Golden and clear. Sweet aroma. Rather smooth;not bad, a mixture of peach and apricot flavors--but not bitter enough for an American IPA in my opinion. 
[Tasted next to a Racer 5]
The Racer 5 is way more bitter, way more grapefruit, and--in my opinion, a better West Coast IPA. That said, the Avery is better than most IPAs and---depending on what youd like--may be preferable.

Orange-yellow color. Lemon Crisp, a little grainy; notceable carbonation. Mild bitterness.
[Compared with a Sierra Nevada Wheat and an Issaquah Bullfrog Ale]
The Anchor is the most bitter and most crisp. The Sierra is the only sorta buttery one. The Isaaquah is the most aromatic. They all taste pretty similar.

Golden-orange color. Lemon-critus aroma. Lemon and orange flavor. Crisp; dry finish.
[Compared with a Sierra Nevada Wheat and an Anchor Summer Beer]
The Anchor is the most bitter and most crisp. The Sierra is the only sorta buttery one. The Isaaquah is the most aromatic. They all taste pretty similar.

Yellow-golden color and a little hazy. Light lemony citrus scent. Sweet and a little buttery; very mild bitterness.  
[Compared with an Issaquah Bullfrog Ale and an Anchor Summer Beer]
The Anchor is the most bitter and most crisp. The Sierra is the only sorta buttery one. The Isaaquah is the most aromatic. They all taste pretty similar.
UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007

Not much aroma; tastes like milk chocolate and coffee, nice sting but goes down really smooth, kind of creamy. The hazelnut extract is very evident.
[tasted next to a Big Sky Moose Drool Brown Ale]

Light nutty aroma; smooth, flavor is nuts and cherries; dry finish; really nice. 
[compared with Big Sky Moose Drool Brown Ale]
The Moose Drool is more aromatic, more chocalty, and sweeter. The Samuel Smiths is lighter, and has fruit flavors.

Suprisingly good. For whatever reason I was skeptical of a beer brewed within walking distance. But Ill shut up now. Really nice grassy aroma. Very hoppy flavor with good malt and alcohol base. Only problem is--as with all bars--its served too damn cold and Im too impatient to wait for it to warm. But no doubt this is a good one. Unfortunately they were out of cans so I couldnt bring any home for comparison.
beer_name: 21st Amendment Brew Free or Die IPA

review_blob: Let me say first, that Im still far from being a brett fan. I guess its an acquired taste; way too sour for me right now. But this beer is a really nice brett gateway. For one, it isnt overloaded with brett; just spiced with it. Second, watermelon works very very well with brett--if youre unfamilar with brett think cidery sour; so this beer is watermelon with a sour kick. Works very well together. And a perfect craft beer for a hot day.
beer_name: 21st Amendment Hell or High Watermelon Wheat

review_blob: Wow, this ones a kick in the ass. Think powerful IIPA; clean palate; big shot of grapefruit hop on top. Kick ass. Holds up well even at Toronado.

Compared to other harvests, this one is very malty. And yet, its beautiful. Very smooth on the palate and a well-ballanced hop-to-malt flavor. If it werent a harvest it might be too malty but this one is really well calculated.
beer_name: Butte Creek Fresh Hop Organic India Pale Ale

review_blob: UPDATED: JAN 11, 2008
beer_name: Stone Sublimely Self Righteous Black IPA

review_blob: UPDATED: NOV 1, 2007
beer_name: Moylans Hopsickle Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: Draft, Toronado Wet Hop Festival. All of these beers are awesome. In comparison to the others, the Sublimmminal has an apple taste, almost sour, and very smooth on the palate.

Draft, Toronado Wet Hop Festival. Info says its made with all Lake County hops. A standout even among wet hops. Wonderful, clean-tasting fresh hop flavor. Compares favorably with another standout, the Sierra Harvest--the Sierra beating Hop Patootie in the nose, but the Patootie being more of a hop blast.
Draft, Toronado Wet Hop Festival. These are all great beers. In comparison to a lot of the others, this one is very malty, heavier tasting.
A lot coming through in the nose--hop, malt, smooth boozy alcohol. A taste to match. Syrupy alcohol with a hop bite but quite a bit of malt.

As an IPA guy, Ill tell you the hops on this one hit you more in the nose than on the tongue. I think thats the goal here though. The taste is a touch bitter, but mosty the expected lager taste although much richer, sweet, syrupy. Extrordinary lager.
Copper-brown; malty sweet with bitterness and accompanying fruit flavors--the whole aresenal; awesome.
beer_name: Bear Republic Hop Rod Rye Ale

review_blob: Very fragrant--strong tangerine and apricot; hazy orange-peach color; a mouthful of really heavy, malty fruit; leaves warming alcohol and residual fruit. I guess if I have to criticize Id say its a bit heavy, but still a beautiful heavy at that, and it well hides the 9.2abv.  Im a fan.
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Wet Hop IPA - Northern Hemisphere

review_blob: apricot aroma; taste is pretty malty with a good hop sting and some pine flavor; pretty substantial on the palate; not bad, but IIPAs are a tough crowd.
beer_name: Tyranena BGW Hop Whore Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: This is a very malty IIPA, but if thats what youre looking for its really nice. Lots of pine flavor but other than that its plenty of almond malt.
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007

Copper color, light aroma. Gosh I dont know--mediocre beer? or did they just pick a mediocre style? Well, what can I say: I lager--more flavorful than most other lagers--but I guess just not really exciting to me.
Milky apricot color; orange and spice aroma; thick, spicey-orange taste. Im not familiar with this style at all but this one seems like a nice one next to a fire during the holidays.
UPDATED: OCT 30, 2007

Very very sweet tangerine smell; beautiful golden color; whoa, the pine flavor comes on really stong, they aint joking by it being "a bit rough"! This is the first "single hop" Ive had and Im a fan of the entire idea. Especially for someone like me whos relatively new--loves IPAs--and has no idea which hop tastes like what. Reminds of those "doctored beers" Ive read about. As for this one, sure you have to be wanting this pretty distinct taste but I could definitely see bringing this one camping. Ill be buying many more of these "single hop"s. Cheers Bison!
beer_name: Bison IPA Single Hop Series - Simcoe

review_blob:
nice aroma, hops but a lot of scents (fruit?) that I didnt expect; apricot color and just transluscent, not clear; wow, really nice flavor: sorta mild hop sting but a ton of other rich flavors (sorry, Im not very good at matching a flavor to a word, with my eyes closed I probably cant identify a chunk of pineapple, but I know I like it). Not at all the type of IPA I typically like, but I really like this. Just a really nice combo of flavors that all complement the full IPA-dose of hops. Well done.
[tasted next to a Lagunitas IPA]
Not really a good comparison, just happens to be whats next to me. The Lagunitas is really nice but pretty one-dimensional next to this. I like them both.
beer_name: Tyranena BGW Stickin It To The Man

review_blob:
Courtesy of Kramer.
Sure Id find a fault if I could. Roasty and chocalate nose, and a rich chocolate taste to match. Quite a bit like Port Brewing Old Viscosity, except maybe a bit dryer finish (maybe the viscositys more of a port than a stout?). Anyways a superb dessert at the end of an historic night (MJ toast). Thanks Kramer!
Im tasting a dead flat, two-week old growler, but this one has a lot of apricot smell, look and flavor; probably not bitter enough for my taste; but not bad at all.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2007

Nice sweet hop smell; cloudy golden color; interesting taste: lots of apricot along with light but very noticeable hop bite. 
[tasted next to Victory HopDevil]
the Fryes Leap is much lighter, more refreshing, more sting. The Victory is bolder, fuller, maltier.

Pure golden color. Light and clean tasting lots of bitterness, minimal malt taste.
[tasted next to a Sierra Nevada Pale Ale (Bottle)]
The XP is more bitter (even though the Sierra is very bitter too), less malt. Both excellent.

Ummm this is good. This is just the type of Barleywine I like but its not traditional at all. It teeters pretty close to being a double IPA--very hoppy, in the nose and in the flavor. So why dont I just buy IIPAs? Because even Barleywines like this have are way sweeter and smoother with all of that malt. Nice warming alchohol too.

Vintage 2002 (6% ABV). Roasty and bitter, lots of alcohol taste (is that from being aged in Whiskey casks? the alcohol % isnt all that high). Dry finish. Too much alcohol taste for me but otherwise nice.
beer_name: Harviestoun Old Engine Oil Special Reserve

review_blob: Apricot cloudy color. Bitter and sour but the alcohol is really right up front in the flavor in aroma--too much so for my taste.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007
UPDATED: NOV 28, 2007

[Compared with Meantime India Pale Ale]
The Steelhead is very similar color just a touch darker--golden apricot approaching brown. Richer caramel smell. More hop sting, less sour, but still grapefruity.

Light and sour aroma. Hazy apricot gold color, and apricot-grapefruit flavor. A mouthful, tastes almost viscous. 
[compared next to a Mad River Steelhead Double IPA]
The hop sting hits you first, then a rich mouthful of malt, and then a nice little hop sting left over. Nice.
beer_name: Samuel Smiths Organic / Old Brewery Pale Ale
